title: Acute Onset Facial Asymmetry in a Middle-Aged Male: Bell's Palsy
clinical_history: Mr. Ravi Sharma is a 48-year-old accountant who presented to the outpatient clinic with a sudden onset of right-sided facial weakness that developed overnight. He first noticed difficulty in closing his right eyelid and an inability to smile symmetrically when looking in the mirror. He also reported dribbling of liquids when attempting to drink, mild pain around his right mastoid, and increased sensitivity to loud sounds on the affected side. He denies any trauma, recent infections, or similar prior events. No limb weakness or change in speech noticed. Past week, he experienced a mild upper respiratory tract infection that resolved without medication.

nprs.affected_area: right facial muscles (frontalis, orbicularis oculi, orbicularis oris, zygomaticus, platysma)

aggrevating_factors: Chewing, drinking liquids (leads to dribbling on right), trying to speak for prolonged periods, emotional expressions (e.g., smiling, frowning); exposure to cold wind worsens facial discomfort.
picture: Facial droop most prominent on attempted smiling and eye closure. Right eyebrow unable to elevate, incomplete eye closure with Bell's phenomenon, and drooping of the corner of mouth on the right. Mild swelling noted near the right mastoid.
easing_factors: Rest, warm compresses to the face, eye protection (e.g., lubricating drops and eye patch at night), reduced speaking/chewing.
past_history: No relevant neurological or autoimmune history. No diabetes or hypertension. Had chickenpox as a child.
medical_history: Generally healthy; mild allergic rhinitis seasonally.
medications: Recently started on oral prednisolone (60 mg, tapering over 7 days) and advised lubricating eye drops. No chronic medications.
personal_history: Non-smoker, occasional social alcohol consumption. Lives with spouse and two children, moderate occupational stress. No recent travel.
imaging: Not performed at this stage; classic presentation of Bell's palsy, no red flag symptoms necessitating imaging.
